summary: This is a Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General memorandum documenting the final disposition of evidence related to Case Number 2019-010614. It details the transfer of custody of numerous logs and items, including personnel files, observation logs, phone records, and surveillance system components, from the OIG to the Federal Bureau of Prisons on December 19, 2024. The evidence pertains to the detention and death of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Named as the subject of a personnel file (Log 9, Item 1) that was part of the evidence transferred. He was likely a staff member at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Named as the subject of a personnel file (Log 9, Item 2) that was part of the evidence transferred. She was a correctional officer involved in the Epstein case.

events.title: Evidence Disposition Transfer
events.description: Special Agents from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General transferred final custody of evidence related to OIG Case 2019-010614 to Special Investigation Agents of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn.

events.title: Inmate Count Slips
events.description: Multiple inmate count slips (5:00 a.m., 3:00 a.m., 12:00 a.m., 10:00 a.m.) were documented as evidence, indicating routine cell checks on this date at the detention facility.

events.title: Epstein Observation Log
events.description: An observation log specifically for Jeffrey Epstein was maintained, covering this period while he was in custody.

events.title: Epstein Observation Log
events.description: An earlier observation log specifically for Jeffrey Epstein was maintained, covering this period.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center Brooklyn, New York
keyFacts: The document is a formal record of the DOJ OIG transferring custody of a vast amount of evidence to the Bureau of Prisons for Case 2019-010614, which is the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The evidence includes highly specific detention records such as Epstein observation logs, suicide watch logs, inmate count slips, phone logs, and staff personnel files.
Personnel files for staff members Michael Thomas and Tova Noel were included in the evidence transfer.
Surveillance system components, including 18 hard drives from the MCC's NICE VISION camera system, were part of the transferred evidence.
The evidence spans from routine prison logs to specialized monitoring records, indicating a comprehensive investigation into the circumstances surrounding Epstein's detention and death.
